FLUOROURACIL

Indications and doses

Treatment of some solid tumours including gastro-intestinal tract cancers and breast cancer, In combination with folinic acid in advanced colorectal cancer,

By intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion or by intra-arterial infusion

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Superficial malignant and pre-malignant skin lesions,

To the skin using cream

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day for 3–4 weeks (usual duration of initial therapy), apply thinly to the affected area, maximum area of skin 500 cm2 (e.g. 23 cm × 23 cm) treated at one time, alternative regimens may be used in some settings.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intra-arterial use or intravenous use

Avoid (teratogenic).

Considerable caution is necessary if a pregnant woman presents with cancer requiring chemotherapy, and specialist advice should always be sought.

With topical use

Manufacturers advise avoid (teratogenic).

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With intra-arterial use or intravenous use

Manufacturer advises caution.

Known side effects

Specific side effects

rare: cerebellar syndrome, cerebellar syndrome,

notKnown: alopecia, bone-marrow suppression, desquamative hand-foot syndrome (on prolonged infusion), extravasation, hyperuricaemia, mucositis, myleosuppression, nausea, oral mucositis, thromboembolism, tumour lysis syndrome, vomiting, alopecia, bone-marrow suppression, desquamative hand-foot syndrome (on prolonged infusion), extravasation, hyperuricaemia, mucositis, myleosuppression, nausea, oral mucositis, thromboembolism, tumour lysis syndrome, vomiting, erythema multiforme, local irritation (use a topical corticosteroid for severe discomfort associated with inflammatory reactions), photosensitivity,

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA212

Bevacizumab in combination with oxaliplatin and either fluorouracil plus folinic acid or capecitabine for the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer (December 2010)

Bevacizumab in combination with oxaliplatin and either fluorouracil plus folinic acid or capecitabine is not recommended for the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

www.nice.org.uk/TA212 www.nice.org.uk/TA212

Cautions regarding administration

  • With topical use: avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes
  • With topical use: do not apply to bleeding lesions

Advice regarding conception and contraception

With intra-arterial use or intravenous use

Exclude pregnancy before treatment with cytotoxic drugs.

Contraceptive advice should be given to men and women before cytotoxic therapy begins (and should cover the duration of contraception required after therapy has ended).

Regimens that do not contain an alkylating drug or procarbazine may have less effect on fertility, but those with an alkylating drug or procarbazine carry the risk of causing permanent male sterility (there is no effect on potency). Pretreatment counselling and consideration of sperm storage may be appropriate. Women are less severely affected, though the span of reproductive life may be shortened by the onset of a premature menopause.

No increase in fetal abnormalities or abortion rate has been recorded in patients who remain fertile after cytotoxic chemotherapy.

Advice regarding handling and storage

Caution in handling—irritant to tissues.

Prepared medicinal forms of FLUOROURACIL

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
Solution for infusion
Cream
